PROFESSOR: Now, what do
we call these things--

pan out? What do you call these things--
pan out and to make up?
To pan out, to make up. We call these things--
AUDIENCE: Phrasal verbs. PROFESSOR: Phrasal verbs. Phrasal verbs, OK? A verb usually has--

phrasal verbs usually have
one verb and one particle, or it could have two more--

one particle and one
preposition at the end. So what's the difference between
a particle and a preposition?

Does anybody--
what's a preposition?  Give me some examples
of prepositions.
Prepositions. AUDIENCE: In. PROFESSOR: In.
AUDIENCE: Of. PROFESSOR: Of. Of-- O-F, of.

AUDIENCE: From. PROFESSOR: At, from-- OK,
those are prepositions, right? Out, up-- these kind of
look like prepositions,

but they actually
have some meaning. These are called
adverbial particles. Adverbs-- they
have some meaning.

So now, if you turn
to this handout,

which is page 65 in
your course packet.
Page 65.

Do you see where we
left off last time?

OK, this sentence-- compare
these two sentences. Compare these two sentences.

What do we stress
here in this sentence?
AUDIENCE: Looking. PROFESSOR: Looking. OK, looking. She was looking at me.

[INAUDIBLE] She was looking at me. AUDIENCE: She was looking at me. PROFESSOR: She
was looking at me. AUDIENCE: She was looking at me.
PROFESSOR: OK. What about this one? AUDIENCE: Away. PROFESSOR: She--

AUDIENCE: --looked away. PROFESSOR: She
looked away from me. AUDIENCE: She
looked away from me. PROFESSOR: So there's
more stress on away.

She looked away from me. AUDIENCE: She
looked away from me. PROFESSOR: She
looked away from me. AUDIENCE: She
looked away from me.

PROFESSOR: "Look-ed,
look-ed," OK? Linking-- she
looked away from me. AUDIENCE: She
looked away from me.

PROFESSOR: She
looked away from me. AUDIENCE: She
looked away from me. PROFESSOR: OK, so if a phrasal
verb has a preposition,

preposition does
not get any stress. No stress, so it gets reduced.

She was looking at me. She was looking at it. Instead of at-- instead of at,
you say something like "ut."

She was looking at me. AUDIENCE: She was looking at me. PROFESSOR: She
was looking at me. AUDIENCE: She was looking at me.

PROFESSOR: But here,
she looked away from me. AUDIENCE: She
looked away from me. PROFESSOR: She
looked away from me.

AUDIENCE: She
looked away from me. PROFESSOR: OK, so there's
more stress on the last word-- pan out.
AUDIENCE: Pan out. PROFESSOR: Make up. AUDIENCE: Make up. PROFESSOR: Pan out. AUDIENCE: Pan out. PROFESSOR: Make up. AUDIENCE: Make up.

these two sets of examples.

but this is a particle. OK, so we put stress here.

There's no stress here. Stress here, but there

So if you say-- so say this.

on a red light. PROFESSOR: There's
stress here, definitely, because these are content words.

She turned on a red light. AUDIENCE: She turned
on a red light. PROFESSOR: She turned
on a red light.

on a red light. PROFESSOR: She turned

she turned on a red light.
She turned on a red light. OK. And you can get a ticket.

on a red light, but-- AUDIENCE: Sometimes--

you can make a left-- you can make a right turn
on the red light any time.

turn it on, right?
Turn it on. AUDIENCE: Turn it on. PROFESSOR: Turn it on. AUDIENCE: Turn it on. PROFESSOR: Turn it on. AUDIENCE: Turn it on. PROFESSOR: OK.

AUDIENCE: Turn it on.  PROFESSOR: Sometimes
it's easy to tell

whether something is
a particle-- adverbial particle or a preposition.

But sometimes, it's
kind of hard to tell. Most of the time-- not all the time. Most of the time, if you could
put if you could move the word,

then it's a particle. Turning it on-- turning it
on, or turn on the red light.

But let's talk
about your problem. You can't say, let's
talk your problem about.

So that's a
preposition, usually. Any questions about this?

AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] say
this again or based on that, she turned-- turned on--

PROFESSOR: She turned
at a red light. She turned-- there's
more stress in here. She turned on a red light. But here, this one
gets-- she turned on.

So the most important thing
is here it becomes turned on. AUDIENCE: Turned on. PROFESSOR: You
don't say turned on.
Turned on. She turned on-- turn-- she turned on a red light. So the vowel is--
AUDIENCE: --red light. AUDIENCE: She turned on-- PROFESSOR: Where's my chalk?

Here, the first
one would be turn--

"turn-dun,"
"turn-dun," "turn-dun." The vowel is a schwa
because it gets reduced.
But the second one-- AUDIENCE: Turned on. AUDIENCE: Turned on. AUDIENCE: Turned on.

PROFESSOR: --turned on, OK? Turned on. Turned on. The vowels are
different-- turned on.

Turned on-- turned
on a red light. She turned on a red light. Turned on.

OK, today we're going to
try to do three things.

We already talked
about phrasal verbs. And we're going to talk about-- we're going to discuss chapter--

unit 8 of our listening book. And then we're going to
talk about sentence stress

and rhythm. For homework for
Thursday, I want you to read chapter 9 of our
textbook Accurate English

and do unit 7 of
our listening book. For that listening
book, turn to page 95.
This is for homework. Turn to page 95.
This is your-- I'm looking at this book. Something's wrong here.
Keep them separated.
OK, page 95.

Page 95. OK, you have the sentence
under notice, right? Imagine if Wall Street--

did you find those
two sentences starting with imagine on page 95? Yes?

Yes. Everyone-- yes? Page 95. I want you to listen to that
as many times as you need to.
OK? OK. OK. OK, where did that come from?

OK. And then, I want you to come up
with a phonetic transcription.

Analyze the sentences--
the words in bold-- words in bold, especially--
I'm going to write this here.
This is in the first sentence. The second sentence we have--

We have this in the
first sentence, right? Listen very carefully how
the speaker actually says

had known. She's not going
to say, had known. She's going to pronounce it a
little differently because it
occurs in irregular speech. Certain things get reduced.

This one, again, she's not going
to say, they'd have sent him.

She's not going to say,
they'd have sent him. She's going to say it
in a different way.

She's going to reduce
certain sounds. So I want you to write
a phonetic transcription
of this string, like they--
do the linking, too. Do the linking.
And we'll do that on Thursday.  OK.

Let's turn to-- any
questions about the homework?
OK.  Chapter 8 in your book.
Let's turn to page 104 and 105. 104 and 105.
104 and 105-- vocabulary. Vocabulary.

We're going to let

We're going to let you
get back to practicing more productive medicine.

When you get off the phone,

you get back to your studies.

OK, you talk to your

back to your work.

But we just say it. I'll let you get back. I'll let you get
back to your work. OK, I'll let you get back.

Let you get back. OK, this word-- how

it becomes-- oh,

does having a car, having a girlfriend company

Makes no sense. OK, so now, that's
present unreal, OK?

Because you don't have a car. You don't have a
girlfriend right now. And present unreal is something
like, if I were Spider-Man--

if I were Spider-Man-- I'm not Spider-Man, right? If I were Spider-Man, I
wouldn't be living in Boston.

right? That's present unreal. But here, what we
have, actually,

is future hypothetical. It's a little
different because it's something that could happen. So if you look at--

OK, it's the point
of this section is, let's say I went in
went in with-- went in.

Again, went in. Went in-- there's
more stress in win. In-- went in with. Went in-- went in with, OK?

in with a bruise or a cut and you had to bandage me up.

Had to-- I mean,
that's strange, right? Why do you use a

That's because let's say

In any words, there

in English words. And in sentences or phrases,
we have certain words that

by sentence stress.

If you have a sentence
stress, then you get a good rhythm in English.

You don't just stress any
of the words-- any words that you want to
feel like stressing,

but there are rules about that. Why does that happen? That happens because
English is very strange.

I think I told you this
before a couple of times. English is probably
the only language

that are commonly spoken
in the world, which is a stress-timed language.

English is a
stress-timed language. But any of the words
that you can think of-- Korean, Japanese, Chinese--
I don't know [INAUDIBLE].

Thai. Thai. Spanish, French, Italian--
maybe except German.

German is maybe a bit
like stress point. Those are syllable-timed
languages,

meaning if you have
more syllables, it'll take longer time
to say those sentences.

But in English,
it doesn't matter how many syllables you have. What's really important
is the number of stresses.

If, in a sentence, if you have
more stressed syllables or more stressed words, then
it'll take longer time

to say those sentences. So for instance,
cats chase mice.
